snippet: The weak transitional government appeared powerless to stop a militia group from selling oil, an indication that the nation may be at risk of coming apart at the seams.
abstract: Militia group controlled by Ibrahim Jathran, which has blockaded Libya’s main oil ports for more than six months, begins to sell oil for its own accounts even as Prime Min Ali Zeidan repeatedly threatens force; first unauthorized export of oil--lifeblood of Libya's government and economy--offers hint that its weak transitional government may be at risk of coming apart at the seams.

byline.contributor: Suliman Ali Zway contributed reporting from Benghazi.

lead_paragraph: The weak transitional government appeared powerless to stop a militia group from selling oil, an indication that the nation may be at risk of coming apart at the seams.

headline.main: Libyan Militia Selling Oil, Defying the Government
headline.print_headline: Libyan Militia Selling Oil, Defying the Government
